content: As promised, I posted today’s demo on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uTc7KCBbVFI

and I also tweeted it, if you all want to get the word out: https://twitter.com/pnkfelix/status/1489334606176428032

http://Pernos.co Demo for Rustc Reading Club, 2022-02-03 https://youtu.be/uTc7KCBbVFI via @YouTube

- Felix S K II (@pnkfelix)

I’m hoping to keep iterating on how I explain this great system to people. (and continue to gain expertise using it!) In the meantime, I hope you all got inspired to maybe try out one of the links from the hackmd. (If someone wants me to upload their playpen on my rustc build, let me know. Although, maybe wait until close to the end of the month, so I don’t have to worry about rationing out my credits.)

Hey y'all, just wanted to share: That posted video, specifically the struggle we were having in finding the used_binding.ambiguity field, led to the pernos.co developers realizing that there was an issue. (Something with the system aggressively filtering out struct fields whose value is None)
and they fixed the bug. (This is one of the really cool things about debuggers as a service applied to a trace: Totally seamless upgrades.)

pnkfelix said:

Hey y'all, just wanted to share: That posted video, specifically the struggle we were having in finding the used_binding.ambiguity field, led to the pernos.co developers realizing that there was an issue. (Something with the system aggressively filtering out struct fields whose value is None)

We should do this again. No telling what an alternate purpose for the debugger might reveal next. I'm very interested in how we might use Pernosco for inspecting and learning unfamiliar code in rustc.

@pnkfelix we need you to come back for another excellent demo with that perspective. The Notebook looks like it will be instrumental in how we might repurpose the service. squad goals! :smile:

This document is superb. If you are attending or planning to attend RRC in the future, Pernosco will continue to be an important tool for us.

@pnkfelix created this excellent discussion of the service in addition to the video he posted. It will be helpful to get a sense of Pernosco before using it during a session to inspect rustc code.

https://hackmd.io/_BnRFW1hRfidntrUC4oc7A
